original: Bergmann, Olga Lovisa, fil. lic., läroverksadjunkt, studierektor, Göteborg, f. 29/12/85 i V. Frölunda, Gbgs o. Boh. 1., av Alex. Bernh. Lorentzon o. Olivia Olsson. G. 16 m. banktj :m. Friedrich Bergmann. Barn: Fritz f. 16, banktj :m., g. m. Ebba Klint-Högström, Ellen 20, g. m. Henrik Gold-kuhl, Inga-Lisa 22, anst. v. sv. leg. i Washington, Sven-Arne 27, fil. stud. i Gbg. — Stud:ex. v. Gbgs samsk. 09, fil. mag. i Gbg 11, fil. lic. 27, provår v. Gbgs real 12. Stud:res. t. Tyskl. 09, 13, 13-14, 15, 16, 19-20, 25, 26, 29, 36, Engl. 33, 34, 35 o. 38. Lär. v. S. Rudebecks sk. i Gbg 11-12, Vasa flicksk. i Gbg 13-14, ämneslär. i Malmköp. 14-15, timlär. i Math. Halls sk. f. fl. i Gbg 18-19, v. Fruntimmersfören. flicksk. i Gbg 18-20, v. Kjellbergska sem. 19-20, part. vik. lektor v. Gbgs real 28, ämneslär. v. S. Rudebecks sk. o. Gbgs gymn. f. fl. 22-30, adj. v. Gbgs latin 30, ämneslär. v. Gbgs h. a. 1. f. fl. 30, adj. där sed. 37, studierektor v. Gbgs gymn. f. fl. sed. 35. Medl. av lärov:sakk. 31-32, led. av priva-^istndn i Gbg 43 o. 44, led. av LMS centr:styr. o. arb:utsk. sed. 38, v. ordf. i Gbgs lokalfören. av LMS 42, led. av styr. f. Sigrid Rudebecks sk. sed. 35. Skr.: övers. Rud. Goldscheid : Fredsrörelse o. människoekonomi (16), K. Gibran: Profeten (33), R. Fülop-Miller: Helgonen som fört världen framåt (47).
translated:
Bergmann, Olga Lovisa, Fil. Lic. (Doctor of Philosophy), Senior Secondary School Teacher, Study Director, Gothenburg, born on December 29th, 1885 in Västra Frölunda, Gothenburg and Bohus County, the first child of Alexander Bernhard Lorentzon and Olivia Olsson. She married bank clerk Friedrich Bergmann in 1916. They had four children: Fritz, born in 1916, who became a bank clerk and married Ebba Klint-Högström; Ellen, born in 1920, who married Henrik Gold-kuhl; Inga-Lisa, born in 1922, who worked for the Swedish embassy in Washington; and Sven-Arne, born in 1927, who studied Philosophy in Gothenburg. 

Olga Lovisa graduated from the Gothenburg Grammar School in 1909 and received her Doctor of Philosophy degree from the University of Gothenburg in 1911. She completed a postgraduate year at the Gothenburg Real School in 1912 and continued her studies in Germany in 1909, 1913, 1914, 1915, 1916, 1919, 1920, 1925, 1926, 1929, and 1936. She also visited England in 1933, 1934, 1935, and 1938. 

She worked at various educational institutions including S. Rudebeck's School in Gothenburg from 1911-1912, Vasa Girls School in Gothenburg from 1913-1914, Malmköping as a subject teacher from 1914-1915, Math. Hall's School in Gothenburg as a temporary teacher in 1918-1919, Fruntimmersföreningens Flickskola in Gothenburg from 1918-1920, Kjellberg's Seminary as a part-time substitute teacher in 1919-1920, Gothenburg's Real School as a part-time substitute teacher in 1928, S. Rudebeck's School and Gothenburg's Gymnasium from 1922-1930, and Gothenburg's Latin School as an adjunct from 1930. She also worked as a subject teacher at Gothenburg's High School from 1930 and as an adjunct there since 1937. She was appointed as a Study Director at Gothenburg's Gymnasium in 1935. 

She served as a member of the school committee from 1931-1932, a member of the Private Schools Committee in Gothenburg in 1943-1944, a member of the Central Committee and Working Committee of LMS (Svenska Missionsförbundet) since 1938, Vice-Chair of LMS's Gothenburg Local Association in 1942, and a member of the Board of Sigrid Rudebeck's School since 1935. 

She wrote the translations of Rudolf Goldscheid's "Peace Movement and Human Economics" in 1916, Kahlil Gibran's "The Prophet" in 1933, and R. Fülöp-Miller's "The Saints Who Moved the World Forward" in 1947.

memberOf.name: LMS (Svenska Missionsförbundet) Central Committee and Working Committee

translator.name: The Saints Who Moved the World Forward
translator.author: R. Fülöp-Miller
